narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Great class! Really liked the structure.

There was a field trip to Seattle/Tacoma to learn about their drinking water systems. The field trip was very useful, but the schedule was too intense with very long days. By the end of the week many of the students were ill and exhausted.
Deal with real problems and learning skills that can be applied to a lot of other problems
Delving deeply into a topic and asking hard questions that don't necessarily have an answer..Being able to spend time with a variety of experts both in class and at dinner.
The course structure. I thought Brad, Mark, and Caitlin did a great job in conceptualizing how the course would progress and build upon itself.
The interdisciplinary nature of the course and ability to work with students coming from different backgrounds.
Interdisciplinary work. Working on a timely, relevant question. Great field trip.
Meeting and learning for all of the industry experts in MA, CT, NY and WA was the most valuable part of the course.

The professors did just enough teaching and allowed/facilitated discussions very effectively. The field trip to Seattle was excellent, very well organized and designed, and added alot to the class. The panel discussions with experts in the field were great.
Great question was asked, and we spent the entire class pursuing it - definitely a worthwhile endeavor.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The course will be different every year as the topic will change, but overall, this semester the topic just seemed to be a bit too far out into the future. The more we explored the ways that water utilities are trying to quantify the benefits of source water protection programs, the more we realized that no one has really tried it. This made it difficult for us to come up with good recommendations as to how to do it. A topic that is a bit more well developed might make for a better course next time.
None.
More deadlines and initial feedback for big paper (e.g. lit cited, outline)
The schedule for the spring break trip needs to be less structured.
Not much. Good class.

Perhaps a bit more background reading, and the very outset, would have been useful. Our question was open-ended, but I felt like some papers and others materials had addressed it before, or at least aspects of it. It might have been useful if we had all discussed a few ideas, right or wrong, before diving into our own research. Although maybe the profs wanted to keep things very open-ended in order to keep us from putting any constraints on our own research/conclusions, which is also valid.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Brad has been tremendously helpful throughout the class by offering us his insights and listening and answering to our concerns.Same with Caitlin
All instructors and the TA were extremely helpful.
They were all very helpful!
Very good. The TA did most of the logistics planning for the field trip and she did a very good job on that
Yes.
Excellent on all fronts. Brad, Mark and Caitlin were great!
any assistance requested was given.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: It is so far my favorite class at FES. I learnt so much from thinking through the problem we are trying to deal with.And finally feel that I am down on the ground helping solving a real life problem not just learning the theories.
This is an "interdiscplinary" course perfect for the MEM program. Also, this course is solving a problem that hasn't been solved yet so it's very applicable to the real world.
Interested on progressive, integrative approaches to watershed management. This class have Mr the opportunity to explore these.
Forests provide many non-timber benefits, like water, and this class was an in depth look at water provision and the relationship between land and forest management and water quality.
fantastic capstone course!

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Interested in the topic
Mark and Brad are two of our best professors and the opportunity to delve into water/watershed issues with them was too unique to pass up.
I thought it would help me learn how landowners could earn income from land that was part of a public drinking water supply watershed.
The topic and the professors.
Interdisciplinary. Project-based.
It was an interdisciplinary course dealing with water issues.

To gain expertise in the field of watershed management and water quality as an ecosystem service provided by forests. Also, to better understand the multiple dimensions and disciplines involved in holistic watershed management.
i'm interested in the subject matter and like the professors, and also saw that the students would be a good group.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Far better than I thought it would be!!!!
Yes!
It didn't quite meet the expectations I had going in, but those expectations changed and overall, I learned quite a bit from the class.
Yes.
Yes!
It fell a little below my expectations.
Definitely, great class.
yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes. way more than what I expected.

Yes and no - my work load in other classes was also so great that I wish I really had more time to spend with the material... while we were each working in our own disciplines, there is still so much else about the other disciplines that is so important to decision-making but I don't necessarily feel like I have a much greater grasp on those topics -
Yes.
Yes and more.
Yes.
yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I think the format of the group work works really well. By bringing people with different expertise together and give us space to communicate, the class expose us to a situation we all need to deal with once graduated: try to communicate and work with people with different background and interests. I learnt a lot from just working in my group about communication and how to align different people's interests.
What is there to say? Like any group work, some people make it a priority and some people push it to a back-burner. It's something we will all have to get used to in the real world.
There was a lot of work involved so the group work helped eliminate the work for one person.
Learned from colleagues. Difficult to schedule.
Advantages - everyone brings a different perspective to the projectDisadvantages - it is difficult to write a unified paper with such different perspectives

Advantages: Learning to work with a team on a professional project with deadlines and high expectations for the quality of deliverables.Disadvantages: Dealing with differences in working styles, expectations, communication, etc.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take full advantage of the class. It is a class for practitioners !!!!!
Do your research/work early, don't put it off or you will be sorry!
Begin working on your group paper early and diligently.
Take it! Very applicable to the real world.
Be aware that you are (trying to) answer a very difficult question that industry experts can't answer. There is a lot of uncertainty in this course.

Be prepared to work hard, but realize that these type of courses are definitely doable and perhaps the best type of class offered at FES. This is what the professional world is like - tough/challenging problems with no clear answer that requires lots of teamwork, abstract thinking, and synthesis of disparate subjects, ideas, concepts, and innovative thinking.
